weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Getting close to the launch of OAuth passthrough from the database in Omni. This would allow Omni to absorb any per-user permissioning from the database.

Lots of spreadsheets

Now you can bring your spreadsheets to Omni. We're not talking CSVs, we're talking real spreadsheets, formulas and all. We'll even intelligently map to live workbook tabs for easy import/export workflows with live data.

We removed the row limit on Excel downloads - formulas, formats, and all. Now the Excel 1M row limit is your only constraint.

Sometimes you actually just want a full spreadsheet on your dashboard tabs and all. Now you can.

For folks in the spreadsheet beta, we've built a converter from the single-tab experience into our new multi-tab spreadsheets.

Now you can bring your spreadsheets to Omni. We're not talking CSVs, we're talking real spreadsheets, formulas and all. We'll even intelligently map to live workbook tabs for easy import/export workflows with live data.

Sometimes you actually just want a full spreadsheet on your dashboard tabs and all. Now you can.

We overhauled the dbt configuration workflow enabling more flexibility and clearer mapping to all the complexity you may have in your dbt setup.

Lots of vis

Final touches on trellis charts - label controls, independent axes, and some tuned up config.

Now heatmaps and boxplots are unlockable in Vega Lite for any long tail customization.

Quickie, but added a control to turn on and off infinite map scroll on flat maps can have infinite scroll or a single-globe flat view.

Few improvements to the pie label experience.

Turns out using HTML in our KPI tiles isn't friendly with every character. Now ampersands and other HTML work the way they should in text boxes.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A first look at adding new model context based on an AI session. This means when you need to introduce new fields or context in a given AI session, Omni can suggest changes to make Blobby smarter for future users and use cases.

Sometimes you want the filter experience to be faster than the back and forth to the warehouse. Now you can create extracts do slice and dice instantly. Lots of work to come here to tune the experience.
In rare cases, folks want to scroll through more than 50k rows in the browser. Now these massive lists can be paginated, including pivots and row totals.
Sometime you need hundreds of tabular rows in your scheduled reports. Now Omni will unfurl long tables in the renderer, allowing users to export hundreds or thousands of rows into documents.
Now stack order can be set independently from the table, for use cases like stacking based on size on a segment-by-segment basis.
Now builders can visually curate the fields available via the front end. Simple workflows for controlling the exact experience for end users.
Early look at a new layer to add a quick summarization for visualizations alongside the vis itself.
Blobby can now move between topics, and the MCP service is available behind a feature flag.

A quick demo of migrating a legacy dashboard via MCP - simply paste in a picture of a dashboard and Omni + Claude (via MCP) builds a replica on top of the Omni data model, styled to match the existing dashboard. Plan to bring this to the native product over time as well.
We improved the workflow for building groups in Omni to make sure it's more ergonomic to build long lists in our modals.
More work to streamline content and model edits in branches for non-downtime dashboarding as models evolve.

Another heavily redacted (sorry) use case of Omni internally using the new spreadsheets. This is a sales ops use case where we're lifting our sales forecasting process from Google Sheets into Omni alongside our live data. Reach out if you need more detail on this one.
A quick example of doing data analysis via the Omni MCP server. Some nice back and forth between the warehouse and analytical interpretation.
Now faceted charts / trellis / small multiples allow for stacked and multi-measure charts.
There's a new option for automated authentication in Omni (Microsoft Entra)
We tuned up navigation for dashboards and layering in pagination for long lists.
Now Blobby is smart enough to run queries prior to summarization for questions where Blobby doesn't already have the answer.
We improvement the table migrator in the model to allow for no-downtime migration of logic for name-changed or deleted views.
A new argument for tuning the ignore behavior with extensions and templated models.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A deep dive into all the special work we put into EAV modeling. Between some API workflows for dynamic field creation and per-customer model extensions, Omni now has a best-in-class approach to one of the most complex database structures. And of course this now unlocks all of the AI workflows on-top of these complex structures too.

Blobby has a new superpower. Now when folks want multi-stage queries Blobby can create filter-by-query UX on the fly (think 'show me spend growth of user spend for customers that made a first purchase in 2020').
Lots of work to make sure scheduled dashboards look great. Now dashboards will intelligently chunk into paginated PDFs for the paper lovers out there.
We've got resizing working smoothly on trellis charts. Few more finishing touches and these should be in customer hands.
The content validator is getting smarter. Now we'll clearly differentiate branch-specific drafts for better triage of model impact.
We're working on lifting the Omni MCP server into the Omni deployment. This and auth are the final steps to getting Omni MCP in customers' hands.
AI context everywhere. This time you can add connection/model ai_context for routing Blobby inside multi-connection deployments.
A quicker way to group fields in the data table directly from the context menu.
We're now logging all of the permissions changes at the content level. Will add to the analytics available to admins soon.
We sped up dashboards by optimizing the content menu a bit. Will be especially efficacious on the largest dashboards.
In our most meta demo of all time, we start taking a look at our demo video data. Will get this loaded into analytics for folks who want to more easily browser the archives with some structure.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Our first version of Omni's MCP service in the wild via Claude desktop. Now you can bring governed data AI anywhere you want. Apologies for some hiccups with screen share early in the video, but some visuals at the end.

We're still working on getting full spreadsheet UI into public GA. The approach is shifting from single-tab visualization to being able to draw from multiple tabs, for any use case you can imagine. Soon.
A new model mode to expose every implicit argument on anything in the data model. This makes the entire model construction explicit for simpler debugging in complex situations.
We wanted to make it simpler to understand the raw schema in isolation, so soon the schema model will be viewable independently.
An early look at building markdown visualizations with AI. Plenty more work to do, but plan to allow completely custom visualization via markdown through this approach.
We're adding contracts and invoicing into Omni for easier coordination and understanding of payment status.
We demo an internal mini app for searching and parsing documents in Omni via Snowflake Cortex. This use case is for contract lookup, but could be extended to any document based analysis.
A for-now internal facing release notes app to understand all of the fresh code in Omni and get plain english understanding of who and what it impacts.

videos.title: Model Debug Mode
videos.description: A new model mode to expose every implicit argument on anything in the data model. This makes the entire model construction explicit for simpler debugging in complex situations.
videos.author: Conrad Slimmer

videos.title: Model Schema Viewer
videos.description: We wanted to make it simpler to understand the raw schema in isolation, so soon the schema model will be viewable independently.
videos.author: Conrad Slimmer

videos.title: Markdown AI Vis Generation
videos.description: An early look at building markdown visualizations with AI. Plenty more work to do, but plan to allow completely custom visualization via markdown through this approach.
videos.author: Jamie Davidson

videos.title: Billing in App
videos.description: We're adding contracts and invoicing into Omni for easier coordination and understanding of payment status.
videos.author: Chris Merrick

videos.title: Document Search Mini App
videos.description: We demo an internal mini app for searching and parsing documents in Omni via Snowflake Cortex. This use case is for contract lookup, but could be extended to any document based analysis. Let us know if you'd like to see the code here.
videos.author: Chris Merrick

videos.title: Release Notes AI Search
videos.description: A for-now internal facing release notes app to understand all of the fresh code in Omni and get plain english understanding of who and what it impacts.
videos.author: Jiro Wiseman

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: The full AI experience is now embeddable, including complete whitelabel options to style and name your AI. Everything Omni + AI + your app.
We shrank the dashboard grid, for finer grain layout control. Plus now when you copy dashboard text and markdown tiles they'll retain full style (shape, background, etc).
We're continuing to build out the AI-only experience, layering in charting controls as you chat to query.
We've added some quicker helpers to instantly name and describe your fields in Omni - better metadata for AI to use plus ease of use for end users.
Our embedded analytics are getting better, this time with our internal changelog, so you can see everything we're shipping on your time.
We're bulking up access grants for more complex use cases. Now you can structure more complex permissions logic using or between attributes for layered AND / OR grants.
Now you can mix and match between fixed (2025-01-01) and relative (3 days ago, 1 month from now) in the filter UX. All AI friendly as well, for any time filter you can imagine.
We took some time to polish the click and hover experience on tables to make drilling and linking simpler and prettier in Omni.
We added search boxes and pagination all over the user management pages for faster admin nav.
Plus we put in some new bumpers to keep Blobby on topic, but made sure it knows the best BI tool on the market :)

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We're bringing a first class AI experience to mobile. So many of the amazing AI use cases are tactical lookups or quick one-off questions. Now they have a first class experience for your phone.

We anonymized our Salesforce data so we could show you all how we actually use AI internally (spoiler - it's actually good). A great example of *actual* self service with all of the governance of an enterprise BI tool.
We're lifting more and more configuration into the front end. Soon you'll be able to build topics fully from the UI.
Continuing work to manage query views from the UI, making it easier to manage and adjust.
Now you can control whether we guess at new visualizations. Helpful when you want to tune queries and make sure visualizations remain static.
More vis work to bring flexible labeling to multi-measure charts.
It wasn't easy enough to filter over future dates like starting two quarters out for two quarters. Now it's a couple clicks.
Blobby is getting smarter. Now AI query can use XLOOKUP to merge queries together like time-series on independent dates.
Now you can build schedules via API, great for bursting and embedded use cases.
Another preview of functionality we'd like to add to the core app. This is an API runner for all sorts of bulk application controls like user or content management.
Another vibe coded app for taking advantage of the Omni API. Let us know if you'd like the code.
More vibe coding, this time for getting Omni content and queries into the Figma UI for high-fidelity design work. So many options on top of the Omni API.
Another mini app example, this time a Typescript SDK on top of the Omni API.
We've added new user-controlled tooling to the app so that users can flip on robust logging to allow us to debug stickier application issues. Just more to keep the app running better for everyone.
We'll now use source to mix table references with jinja references when we push queries back into dbt models.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Now spreadsheets can call data from many tabs at once. This offers the flexibility to run a bunch of queries and then manipulate the results into any spreadsheet layout that makes sense. Little more polish, but will be in beta soon.
We're making it 10x faster to find what you are looking for in the data model. Faceting for fields, topics, views; better search; and a simple UX. Launching soon.

Our AI is getting smarter - now with options to push simple queries to small, fast models or more complex queries to reasoning models. We're also teaching Blobby to build calculations using the Excel syntax for even more complex query construction.
We're overhauling the front end experience for views and topics to make everything UI controllable, more clear, and faster to work with. Here we show off the new experience landing soon.
It can sometimes be tricky to immediately understand the types of queries possible. Sample queries offer a way to curate out examples to enable better end user self-service.
We added a bunch of options for calendar visualization to the library - including timeline style (a la Github) or classic calendar view.
Now legend selection and de-selection is available for stacked bar chart, using both color faceting or multi-series stacking.
Another mini app on top of the API - this time for visually browsing the table model (think ERD for joins, fields, etc).
A quick mini app for migrating data models between Omni environments. Another example of simple workflow on top of the API - especially relevant for dev, staging, prod style deployments.
Another example of what's possible with the Omni API. Here we have a mini app for installing a database connection, data model, and dashboards in a few clicks.
We show off another mini app for managing users and groups inside Omni. Another example of the possibilities using the API for bulk user tuning.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We're adding more layers to the data model for the most complex use cases. Soon user-specific or group-specific models will be layered into the data model. This opens up utilities like localization, departmental models, per-user models, and all sorts of interesting extension points to the app. These will be able to be tied to user attributes for dynamic model layers as well.

The finishing touches on DIY embed navigation - enabling more control and curation over the embed UX. Additionally we've enable navigation without rebuilding the iframe for huge improvements in speed and quality of user experience.
Continuing work to make sure AI always returns results for natural language queries. Plus lots of work to improve recall on time filters.
Now user attributes can be called when adding AI context, for more elegant use cases like data summary with better user context.

We've tuned up the in app analytics experience with a simpler model for user permissions (think way easier to use) and lots of new data on cache hit rates and performance to tune and optimize dashboard loads.
We're improving our test coverage for data filters to make sure we can keep building quickly while minimizing negative customer impact or regressions.

videos.author: Nate Agrin

videos.title: AI Retry and Better AI Filters
videos.description: Continuing work to make sure AI always returns results for natural language queries. Plus lots of work to improve recall on time filters.
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: User Attributes in AI Context
videos.description: Now user attributes can be called when adding AI context, for more elegant use cases like data summary with better user context.
videos.author: Richard Czechowski

videos.title: Better Code Testing
videos.description: We're improving our test coverage for data filters to make sure we can keep building quickly while minimizing negative customer impact or regressions.
videos.author: TJ Banghart

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: You can now filter with calculations post-query! This opens up a huge number of new use cases, filtering rows for visualization (ie trimming off partial moving averages), removing some rows (say hiding rows based on an IF calc), or even just simpler tables with calcs over a larger data set.

We're moving blobby into AWS Bedrock (powered by Claude), to reduce the surface are of where customer metadata is used and simplify subprocessor requirements. We also added new functionality to continue retrying query construction following errors, improving recall.

We added new functionality to the AI web app to side-by-side test different model contexts. This can be used to improve and adjust the data model to optimize query results for natural language use cases. Supports either ad hoc query or a golden test set.
Continuing down the path of making view building in the workbook clearer and faster. Now query views (SQL or UI) get a dedicated build and edit experience.

We improved the dashboard editing experience to exact match the size in production. This means all the visualization tuning will exact match the final product. Additionally, we added a UI toggle to optimize the independent mobile layout (ie won't affect the desktop layout).
We've heard lots of demand for data directly into Google Sheets without Zapier. Now using Google Cloud Run functions, we have secure data transfer into Sheets.
We're launching the new UX for conditional formatting with a first class UX on the table options, including full-row highlighting.
We're launching all the new performance data for query runtimes into production. Lots of granularity on query performance to action better experience for end users.

Several customers have requested the flexibility to build their own app nav. Now folks can DIY application navigation outside the dashboard iframe for even more custom experiences. We added always_where_filter (a forced, hidden topic filter) alongside sql_always_where. Also some additional work to improve cache hit rates.
Continuing work on branches for content for the most mature content lifecycle out there.

Continuing to make the whole app API addressable - here with connection environment building (also landed but not demoed delete folder, import content, moving content, get queries from dashboard). Now models can be deployed cross-environment with git, for multi-instance deployment or dev-staging-prod workflows.
A new admin console for moving data models between environments - best for multi-region deployments or dev-prod workflows.
We're doing some reorg on the docs to make it easier and faster to find what you need. Feedback appreciated on how we can organize for the best experience.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A huge step forward in enriching Omni models for AI. We now have field specific AI context, and helpers for value generation. The net is huge step forwards in AI quality across any use case. Additionally, we added workflow to add query examples to the model AI context for ground truth examples.
Arielle shows the potential of the AI API for building custom natural language apps. Shoot us a note if you want the app code.
We bulked up our docs for training Blobby. Will continue adding here, but lots of lessons to share on improving the model to invite better quality for AI use cases.
We're now passing the model AI context to more places in the app, meaning vis-specific context can be more tactical.
A full UI for managing database load. We've layered in new tools for per-database and per-user throttling, making sure no one person can overwhelm the database.

Lots of work bringing the full content editing experience to branches - now content edits can be synced end to end with dbt changes and the data model for fully robust edits to your most important dashboards.
We added more metadata for schema refreshes to understand where time is spent or any associated errors.
A follow up to our demo from last week. A bit more debug info on the dbt metadata Omni has access to.
We're piping detailed query performance data back the logs - now performance can be traced from dashboards to individual queries, with full timing metadata up and down.

We're opening the beta for editing visualizations directly from the dashboard as we put the finishing touches on the full experience. Now fast edits like KPI layouts, dashboard widths, or really anything vis related.
We extended date fill to more complex filter options, including compound filters (ie relative to fixed date periods).
A beautiful new card visualization for displaying logos alongside a checklist UI.
A few new visualizations for presenting word cloud style data
Some new affordance in the visualization for null data, giving more optionality into displaying sparse data.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We added some new controls. Now series can be toggled on and off vs requiring a field swap. Additionally now tables can be built dynamically by selecting one or many columns.

Continuing the work to improve two-step analytics workflows focused on create dataset then analyze dataset. The new dataset workflow will allow special workbook tabs that build datasets for use across the workbook and more focused controls for building data. More to do here, but great progress.

Lots of new vis

An early look at some richer controls for full row conditional formatting or basing conditional formats on a independent column.

Arielle shows off a new custom visualization for Kanban board data, with responsive columnized cards.

Another new custom vis for zoomable charts for more interactive vis experiences.

A new visualization framework for building metrics trees in Markdown. This is a bit custom, but a nice addition for some tactical use cases with metric trees.

We polished up the labeling on transposed tables that get passed to our visualization layer.
An early look at some richer controls for full row conditional formatting or basing conditional formats on a independent column.
Arielle shows off a new custom visualization for Kanban board data, with responsive columnized cards.
Another new custom vis for zoomable charts for more interactive vis experiences.
A new visualization framework for building metrics trees in Markdown. This is a bit custom, but a nice addition for some tactical use cases with metric trees.
We polished up the labeling on transposed tables that get passed to our visualization layer.

And more for dashboards

We'll now load tiles below the fold after the top of the dashboard, reducing browser load (especially valuable on mobile and less resourced machines). The net is faster dashboards for everyone.

Our dashboard performance tuning tool is now generally available to everyone. Plus a bit of new UX around sorting for quicker tuning.
We'll now load tiles below the fold after the top of the dashboard, reducing browser load (especially valuable on mobile and less resourced machines). The net is faster dashboards for everyone.
Our dashboard performance tuning tool is now generally available to everyone. Plus a bit of new UX around sorting for quicker tuning.

We built a new UX for remapping renamed tables and ensure all of the content and referencing works seamlessly in Omni. Want to build the best tools out there for managing a fluid data warehouse schema.
Welcome to Mariel, shipping some code first week! We've added some deep links to the content validator, to jump right to the broken content for faster fixing.
Bit of tuning to the templated experience to make it work better with filter injection variables.
Little fresh code to make sure column reordering takes advantage of the browser cache and keeps a little load off the database.
More a PSA than anything, but now Omni can be procured through the Snowflake marketplace.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A guest demo from our friends at Ramp Networks demo three new custom visualizations, and have also shared out code for others.

A doubleheader demo of the edit-vis-from-dashboard experience. Couple weeks out from launch, but can see almost all of the visualization controls live on the dashboard - KPIs, color controls (including promotion!), and of course vanilla vis config. Not sure on beta status here but can ping us for an earlier look maybe.
We demo the new spreadsheet-centric UX for CSV upload - trivial to edit and refine the upload, now including type controls to override our type guessing.
A quick demo explaining our CSV upload security model - where developers can move CSVs across workbooks, but they are default locked into the security of the given workbook.

We love emojis at Omni (3000+ and counting). James built a quick new app for showing some rich stats on reactions in Slack (user, day, emoji). A ridiculous amount of fun for us, we're thinking about how to build a small tool for others too.

Bunch of fresh code for some of our most complex environments, smoothing the experience for connection environments plus the interaction with git and user attributes. Making sure even the most complex setups can feel great.
We're continuing to tune up the new workbook page to make all the different types of analysis fast and easy. Currently an internal beta, but rolling out soon.
We made it a little simpler to find field references in markdown (format, drill, etc), so faster and easier custom tile building.
Bunch of new [internal] tools for us to understand and improve performance at granular levels. We'll externalize some of these, but ultimately just want to make sure the app stays fast.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: The launch of docs helpers in our AI experience. Now you can ask blobby about not just data questions or how to interpret the data, but also how to model, visualize, or configure Omni (with deeplinks too).
We're getting close to full vis config controls directly from the dashboard. No more jumping back and forth to the workbook unless you really want to.

Sometime folks need all the data and they need it in email. Sadly most mail providers don't allow that, but now you can schedule unlimited datasets with a call back to download data of any size via Omni.
Some new tooling to make sure Omni metadata stays in sync with your dbt repo. More clarity for understand how Omni sees your dbt environments.
A new demo of richer interaction for a tabbed dashboard experience. This is still a custom markdown object, but we'll look to build into our native experience as well.

We're making it simpler for users to orient in a blank workbook - clear pointers to curated data sets, but also offering more options around other tables in the warehouse or CSV when the use cases may be different.
All the beautiful work to improve color management and simplify interaction is now available for conditional formatting in the data table as well.
A new example of XMR charts in Omni, popularized for process control use cases.

We've heard from customers that you love color modeling, but lots of data sets have columns that need duplicated metadata (say event schemas with a table per event type). Here we show off how to model color once but propagate the metadata to many fields - single place to maintain and push changes.
We show off a new API for moving content between environments that will also be a building block towards fully automated content creation.
We sped up content validation on large models - always striving to make cleanup easier.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We demos three use cases for the open spreadsheet UI. We're excited to see more of these use cases where folks had no other choice but to disconnect from the database. Now everything can wire up to live data and filters!
The launch of CSV pushdown to the warehouse. Works across every dialect Omni supports.

The complement to CSV Uploads - now layering more data into an analysis is as easy as copy paste or a writing data to a spreadsheet. Lots of ongoing work here, but huge new use cases open up instantly.

We show off some in-progress work to streamline all the different approaches to analysis - curated datasets (topics), single-table, CSV input, blank spreadsheets, AI, or SQL. Every company has all of these use cases - let's make sure we can handle them in one place.
We're still working on lifting the full visualization editing experience to the dashboard. No more bouncing back and forth to the workbook unless you want to.

The final step in our color work, now all of the promotion and workflow you have on dimensional coloring is available on measures as well. Easy to tune one-off, dashboard level, or across the entire Omni environment. Elegance in layers.
Now you can complement region and point maps with our new heatmaps. We added a utility to understand how time filters compile, no more guesswork in the result set for inclusive/exclusive
We tuned up the navigation experience to support deeply nested folders - just making it a bit easier to get to everything in a click or two.

Tools for developers:

Now topics are rename-able from the Omni IDE with relabeling or copy-paste. We improved the content validator load experience and made sure it doesn't time out even with the most complex models.

Little fresh code to allow wildcard matching in access filters for more flexible data management.
Now topics are rename-able from the Omni IDE with relabeling or copy-paste. We improved the content validator load experience and made sure it doesn't time out even with the most complex models.
Little fresh code to allow wildcard matching in access filters for more flexible data management.

And more

We added a new tab to our analytics dashboard to understand all the fresh product you can opt in to (thanks to our new input tables). As always, let us know if anything looks interesting to try.

We dolled up the website and tried to make it a little easier to understand who we are and all the use cases we can support.
We added a new tab to our analytics dashboard to understand all the fresh product you can opt in to (thanks to our new input tables). As always, let us know if anything looks interesting to try.
We dolled up the website and tried to make it a little easier to understand who we are and all the use cases we can support.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We brought CSV uploads from workbooks into the database. Now your workbook CSVs can live in the database alongside the rest of your data, in any dialect you are using (yes, all of them).
Now you can touch and feel your CSV uploads. We attached a full spreadsheet to the app for data input or tuning imported CSVs. Now data input is as easy as spreadsheeting.
The final step in our color work - now color mappings on specific visualizations can be pushed to an entire dashboard on the entire customer environment. Color controls up and down the app.
We polished up the content organization model with lots more metadata and navigation to make it easier to build and share dashboards and workbooks.
Sarah shows off more of the potential with markdown visualizations.
We added some new functionality so that markdown builders can see the full Omni payload using {{ inspect }}, clarifying how to call anything in the result set.
A bit of early work to open up heatmaps on our zoomable, pannable maps in Omni.

Tons of improvements throughout the app - we removed the little blue spreadsheet box on tables unless you want it (great for screenshots), KPI alignment improvements, new controls for dashboard tile borders, and even a marketing website refresh.
An early demo of our new dashboard summarization tools - now you can chat with AI about your dashboard and understand takeaways and next steps.
We've done a ton of work to improve the dbt IDE - fast metadata refresh; easier navigation in dbt branches; and full menus for context and actions.
A new internal app for building slide decks using Salesforce data and a little bit of AI, piped to a clean Google slide deck.
Making it that much faster to find the users you're looking for.
New controls to fine tune support access to customer environments.
We're doing lots of work to make sure the app stays performant at extremely high concurrency.
James shows off an internal app to quickly look up logs in AWS through intelligent deep links.
Arielle demos a dashboard bringing together lots of new product - an uploaded dataset of each Omnis walk-out song plus some Snowflake Cortex functions to tell folks about everyone's song choices.

videos.title: Perf Work

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: The soft launch (feature flag) of CSV upload, plus lots of conversation around lifecycle management. Note this will work in any supported dialects in Omni.
Now filters can cache indefinitely (well 30 days), but enough that they should never load fresh on a dashboard unless that's explicitly desired.

We extended modeled colors and front-end value controls to pie charts. We also brought the final modeled piece to the UI with else colors to highlight specific sections. The final touch will be promotion workflows.
Smart labels have launched, and we added a release valve to force labels as well, for complete control when it's desired alongside the collision-less experience.
We've added to tabs to our Omni analytics dashboard for simpler navigation, better organization, and faster performance.

Putting some of the final touches on the dashboard performance analysis tool - clarity on cache hits, data size, and load times across each tile of the dashboard. We want to give data teams a full product suite for managing performance.
Quick demo of a desktop Omni app built for quick customer lookups. A great example of using embedded Omni + ChatGPT to build quick utilities. Hit us up if you want the code.
We've been doing some work to enable compound cross-tab references (ie XLOOKUP with concatenated keys). Just makes life a bit easier for the complex use cases.
Demo of a new workflow to connect Omni content into Google Slides seamlessly via Zapier
The final step in our drafts work - some in progress work on lifting drafts into branches so several folks can iterate on dashboards together, including model or dbt changes.

An early demo of new work to make support an entirely model-less experience. We're building first class support for CSVs, tables, or even blank spreadsheets alongside the data model, pairing quick analysis to the deeper workflows and governance in the data model. More to come here.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Filtering can be hard - not knowing which field to pick or how to express a complex time grain. Filter AI means filter is as easy as a text box. Work to do here still, but the potential is enormous for changing the way end users build and refine queries.

This is the first app bringing together our new spreadsheet functionality alongside core BI use cases to build a real-time, permissioned commissions payment tool for sales ops. Now sellers can see all quoted sales alongside payment structure, with infinite flexibility to control payout structures or bonus via the breadth of a spreadsheet. No more importing and exporting and munging - now everything can be tied back to the sources of truth and update in real time.

Modern data teams operate like product teams, tools are delivered, but then need to be monitored and tuned, especially for performance. This is an early look at rich new tools for understanding performance (querying, data movement, rendering, etc) and finding hotspots to improve the end user experience.
Time is hard. Everyone in BI has experienced it. Our new filter helper explains what time filters mean in plain language to make it easier.

A new per-user page to easily expose all the user attributes for the given account. This makes cloning attributes simple and obviates understanding the full permission set for a given user (sorry IT issues mean no sound on this one).
We're still improving themes, now with control for dark/light mode explicitly, and themes that can be tied to visualization color palettes for complete cohesion and control of the visuals.
We've taught Blobby how to work with docs. Now users can ask for help building queries or just generally using the application and Blobby can point to resources to get folks unblocked quickly.
More work on long-running queries to enable ~unlimited downloads via Omni.
We show off a few of the new demo data sets and dashboards

We've begun porting some of the AI workflows to Bedrock in AWS (Claude for the curious). This means data never leaves the AWS envelope, reducing sub-processors and app surface area. This also means we can make the deeper AI functionalities available to anyone with more strict security postures (sorry IT issues mean no sound on this one).
New shortcuts for bulk dash layout changes - now tiles can zip to the top or bottom without the drag-rearrange challenges on longer dashboards.
Sarah again shows off the possibilities for building pixel perfect, rich layouts in Omni using modern web techniques. Next step will be markdown templates to easily import these approaches.
We prettied up the login page, making sure the app is staying as fresh as all the new code we're shipping.
New APIs for importing Omni models across environments or connections. Important tools for the most complex deployments.
Some new tools (first internal, later external) to share out more detail on fresh code landing in product.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A new labeling algorithm that means no overlapping labels. Beautiful scatterplots, lines, bar charts right out of the box. Rolling out shortly.
Probably our most persistent bug is now in the past. Lots of structural work to improve our URL structure and metadata storage to make sure tiles aren't moving or changing in unexpected ways.

The first in a series of work to lift a bunch of the editing experience for visualization to the dashboard itself. Making sure builders have all the relevant tools in both the workbook and on the dashboard. Part one covers titles and descriptions, more to come.

Some new work to build visualizations using natural language. These are all using the UI chart builder, so remain editable by end users. We hope to unify more of the AI interactions in the future, but continuing to press AI into all the different facets of the app.
Now the cache is fully in your control - we have a new API to purge the cache. This means the cache can be tied to changes upstream - ETL cycles, dbt runs, or simply because you have new data.
More work on nested folders in the content management system, including some discussion of permission inheritance.

We show a nice workflow for deploying embedded dashboards - here we use the API to tie dashboards in a folder to the sidebar navigation in production. This means deploying new dashboards to customers can be as easy as a prod folder in the Omni environment - easy build and deploy.
Colors are great, but we're not stopping there - we've lifted transparency controls everywhere you find colors. Also available through 8-character hex codes. More tools, cleaner finished product.
Continuing the work to speed up embed auth and make every embedded dashboard faster.
Pair of demos to smooth out the drafts experience - final touches on locked read-only field picker + now we'll make sure to save even un-run SQL on save.
A quick look at some new fancy gauge charts.
We show some workflows to build dashboard themes using AI. This means folks can feed in app styles to quickly build new embed themes in Omni.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Bring any date you want into the workbook - Now users can mash-up ad hoc data sets with the database - targets, custom enrichment, or even one-off data sets for dashboards. These new data sets operate like first class workbook queries - SQL access, Excel formulas, visualization, anything. Rolling out over next few weeks.
The launch of AI summary tiles to explain and analyze visualizations, including hooks for tuning prompts for specific use cases.
Advanced Vega visualizations mean no cliff for building to completely custom use cases - now those visualizations can be wired to the UI for easy building and configuration (and later installation).
A quick demo of how embed users can share dashboards + filters or explorations using new framework for URL sharing even in the iframe.
Adding some new projections to our mapping tools for better full globe visualizations (or the non-believers)
Always striving to get to 100% on polish in the visual experience. Bunch of polish on table charts to give flexibility on labeling and give designers the tools to make beautiful visualizations
More buildout of use cases with Snowflake Cortex - sentiment, summarization, and some more polished use cases with NBA data.
A cute demo of a small spreadsheet template and the new functionality that opens up with a complete spreadsheet UX.
We put a bunch of work into a new path for embed to massively speed up user authentication, even with lots of attributes, plus some conversation about the future.
A new (internal for now) toolkit for performance testing with lots of metrics. Need great tools to make sure things stay fast end-to-end.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Bunch of new APIs we're launching for content, plus some conversation about our prioritization for new APIs (TLDR; ask us if you need APIs).

Lifting all of the color modeling work into the UI - now dimensional colors can be set explicitly in the UI (think completed = green, returned = red). Final step will be promotion to the model, for end-to-end color controls with all of the governance depth you could want for later.
Early look at a new vis type that will summarize query results into a succinct text summary, with small hook for prompt tuning. This will launch with our new AI controls for data sharing.

The first step towards getting the full picture of how all of the content in the systems (dashboards, workbooks, etc) is using topics, views, and fields in the data model. This will be the core building block for maintaining and improving the system as the database and data models evolve.

Sarah shows off some beautiful new KPI tiles for displaying a series of metrics and orienting the current metric vis-a-vis a historical distribution. Gives a nice flavor for the possibilities with our KPI visualizations.

We rebuilt our custom visualization templates to more easily wire to diverse data tables (ie. only plug series in in one place). This will underpin the work to then present front end controls on custom visualizations. (Plus a quick demo of our cross-filter vis)

A smorgasbord of odds and ends to make the experience better. Bit more work on nested folders and navigation, clearer filter icons in the workbook when views and groups are collapsed, new /analytics quick URL builder from any dashboard, and longer vanity URLs for dashboards to help a couple customers with longer dashboard names.
In anticipation of bringing some beta testers into the open spreadsheet experience, we're making sure styles feel aligned with the rest of the Omni app (colors, fonts, borders, etc).
Some silent work in the background, but continuing to make it easier to build and support more visualization controls in the future
Bit of refinement to the model and admin process with dynamic schemas.
New facet in the content validator to filter between public and private content.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: We show how to take advantage of Snowflake Cortex to enrich data in Omni using modern LLMs. We show several examples of enriching marketing data, even layering interactive UI for selecting models or tuning prompts.
An early look at nested folders. Coming soon!
Continuing to enrich our dbt workflows, now layering in direct model editing (via pull request) in the Omni UI. Also layering in file search for the dbt viewer.
New support for complex joins (inequality, multi-condition, etc) in the UI. Continuing to lift as much of the modeling experience as we can into the UI.

Putting the finishing touches on a URL rebuild for workbooks to stamp out the issue of dashboard tiles rearranging after workbook edits. This was a bigger lift than we expected, but excited to put it in the past.
An early look at vertical reference lines on charts. Still work to do, but more actionable, clear charts coming soon.
Now schedules can take advantage of dashboard controls for field swapping in delivered content.
Continuing the build out of color controls in the model - now supporting measures (especially useful with filtered measures)
Filter settings on the dashboard now allow for tooltips to add more metadata to dashboard filters
Bit of tuning to subtotals to allow subtotaling over pivots as well.

More for developers

Unveiling a new API for model building

Speed is a first class category of work for Omni. Continuing the focus on keeping the app speedy through high concurrency, and hammering out hotspots.

New toggle to trust certificates in MSSQL - supporting a default configuration for Microsoft customers

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets:
Bunch new AI features

Inviting new questions in a topic to get oriented on the data available

Summarize query results and point at follow-up analysis (we have some data processing pieces to solve there prior to release)

Some new tuning to AI query to improve filter construction using more structured LLM endpoints. Plus some improvements to make sure global AI query (outside of topics) is more scalable on larger models.
Inviting new questions in a topic to get oriented on the data available
Summarize query results and point at follow-up analysis (we have some data processing pieces to solve there prior to release)

Some new tuning to AI query to improve filter construction using more structured LLM endpoints. Plus some improvements to make sure global AI query (outside of topics) is more scalable on larger models.
We're exposing a bunch more topics for exploration of Omni usage data. Also an early look at model metadata - exposing field usage across the app, and workbook vs shared model for dashboards.
Some detail into recent load testing for high concurrency deployments, plus a bunch of the fixes we put in place to improve response time with high concurrency.

A bit of front-end

New folders for organization branches (just use "/"), plus alphabetical ordering.

Few small improvements to vis - bringing color controls to pie charts and some tuning for line weights in charts.

Adding a new swath of internationally friendly time formats to vis.

We now support arrays in user attributes with multiple values in SQL calls using IN()

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets:
A pair of huge new features for streamlining the dashboard experience:

Multi-select controls that allow for building a table from an array of columns that can be dynamically chosen (think pick N of the selected columns through a filter)

Tile-specific controls that lift the column picking interaction from the top of the dashboard on to one specific tile in-line (still needs design, but huge interactivity win)."
Multi-select controls that allow for building a table from an array of columns that can be dynamically chosen (think pick N of the selected columns through a filter)
Tile-specific controls that lift the column picking interaction from the top of the dashboard on to one specific tile in-line (still needs design, but huge interactivity win)."
We're making Blobby smarter - now rather than forcing selection Blobby can find the best topic to answer your question. Makes querying that much easier for end users.

More in the model:

A new else field for coloring dimensions, giving more flexibility for color settings over highly fragmented dimensions. Also a bit of discussion of all the ways to format colors (RGB, Hex, CSS, etc)

New model control to set topic ordering in the workbook

Couldn't tell you what a Dutch number format is, but now we have them!
A new else field for coloring dimensions, giving more flexibility for color settings over highly fragmented dimensions. Also a bit of discussion of all the ways to format colors (RGB, Hex, CSS, etc)
New model control to set topic ordering in the workbook
Couldn't tell you what a Dutch number format is, but now we have them!

More in the front-end

Some behind-the-scenes work to allow better composability as we create Vega specs for our visualizations. Outcome would be better feature development velocity for vis.

Some new search controls for quickly finding dimensions or measures in the field picker (quick one flagged by a customer).

A quick tweak to add timezone to dashboard runtime metadata for easier undertsanding.

Some helper text to show how promotion should work inside drafts
Some behind-the-scenes work to allow better composability as we create Vega specs for our visualizations. Outcome would be better feature development velocity for vis.
Some new search controls for quickly finding dimensions or measures in the field picker (quick one flagged by a customer).
A quick tweak to add timezone to dashboard runtime metadata for easier undertsanding.
Some helper text to show how promotion should work inside drafts

And some for admins:

Bit more meat on our docs for the embed messaging framework. This opens up lots of UX extensibility for embedded developers for on-load events, on-click events, or a variety of other end user actions.

New admin toggles to only allow support coverage from different regions (North America or Europe or anywhere). May be appropriate for different data protection postures.

Bit more meat on our docs for the embed messaging framework. This opens up lots of UX extensibility for embedded developers for on-load events, on-click events, or a variety of other end user actions.

Bunch of nice IDE polishing - resizable gutter, quick folding, and better dark mode.
A few more color palettes, and some gradients meant to couple nicely with our divergent palettes for more cohesive dashboards.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Totals for everything! Now users can toggle between native totals (ungrouped aggregates), simple totals, min, max, and count on any field. This includes bring flexible totals to dimensions (!) and calculations (!).
Now calcs work seamlessly with controls (field swappers). So dashboards with dynamic timeframes, dimension swappers, and measure swappers can seamless build calculations on top.
More work to polish up our SQL autocomplete system, then a demo of run highlighted SQL for folks that need to test as they build larger SQL statements.
Now in_query works with both fields and views, plus a quick demo of how join trees are handled for in_query. Making sure whatever crazy dynamic field handlers you need are buildable.

A first look at the embedded dashboard building and sharing workflow (embedded content management). Now embedded users can build their own dashboards and share with co-workers just like native app users

Plus some odds and ends:

A preview of the new documentation explaining all of the CSS control for dashboards in Omni.

Some polish to make forms always focus to complete / save on Enter

Now we're sorting favorite alphabetically in the content system

A quick demo of our new in-app toast system

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: Our AI is getting smarter. Now Blobby can answer data questions like suggesting queries or offering follow-up questions. Additionally we've added some metadata hooks in the model to improve how fields are selected, add example values, and more.
Our first guest demo from Chris at CamoAG gives us an overview of the different mapping and tiling systems (and lots of , and shows off a few of the new Omni region mapping visualizations.

Lots of vis:

The general launch of map regions in GA, plus a demo of the new support for rendering these through the scheduler and more intelligent viewport setting when data gets filtered.

Lots of new toggles to make axes exactly right. Now you can hide/show ticks, the axis line, and more.

We polished up the default datetime formats on x-axis to make it more intelligent and easier to read.

Still striving to create a best-in-class SQL writing experience. We overhauled the autocomplete UX to be more intelligent and prettier.
The general launch of map regions in GA, plus a demo of the new support for rendering these through the scheduler and more intelligent viewport setting when data gets filtered.
Lots of new toggles to make axes exactly right. Now you can hide/show ticks, the axis line, and more.
We polished up the default datetime formats on x-axis to make it more intelligent and easier to read.
Still striving to create a best-in-class SQL writing experience. We overhauled the autocomplete UX to be more intelligent and prettier.

More dashboard improvements:

Date filters using between were set to mirror Looker's behavior, which means that the end date was non-inclusive. We've heard lots of feedback that folks don't like that and have now changed the behavior and added an additional tooltip to explain (ie. now 2024-01-01 to 2024-06-01 will include June 1st rather than excluding it).

We finally got to the root of a frustrating bug that was moving visualizations on the dashboard after unrelated edits.

Another demo of the soon-to-release drafts workflow.

Date filters using between were set to mirror Looker's behavior, which means that the end date was non-inclusive. We've heard lots of feedback that folks don't like that and have now changed the behavior and added an additional tooltip to explain (ie. now 2024-01-01 to 2024-06-01 will include June 1st rather than excluding it).
We finally got to the root of a frustrating bug that was moving visualizations on the dashboard after unrelated edits.
Another demo of the soon-to-release drafts workflow.

New tooling that allows database connections to be parameterized via user attributes. This offers some optionality around permissioning (secure connection vs open connection) or even allowing large Snowflake warehouses for specific users or use cases.

We've tuned the handling of embed user permissions. Rather than using connection defaults, now external embed users will require explicit permission setting in the URL construction. This makes app intent more clear and offers more nuance for internal/external shared deployments.
A new API for editing the model.

videos.title: Map Regions Launch
videos.description: The general launch of map regions in GA, plus a demo of the new support for rendering these through the scheduler and more intelligent viewport setting when data gets filtered.
videos.author: Rob Miller

videos.title: Visualization Axis Tick Controls
videos.description: Lots of new toggles to make axes exactly right. Now you can hide/show ticks, the axis line, and more.
videos.author: Nate Agrin

videos.title: Axis Date Format Improvements
videos.description: We polished up the default datetime formats on x-axis to make it more intelligent and easier to read.
videos.author: Nate Agrin

videos.title: SQL Autocomplete Improvements
videos.description: Still striving to create a best-in-class SQL writing experience. We overhauled the autocomplete UX to be more intelligent and prettier.
videos.author: Richard Czechowski

videos.title: Change to Date Endpoints with Filters
videos.description: Date filters using between were set to mirror Looker's behavior, which means that the end date was non-inclusive. We've heard lots of feedback that folks don't like that and have now changed the behavior and added an additional tooltip to explain (ie. now 2024-01-01 to 2024-06-01 will include June 1st rather than excluding it).
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Bugfix for Dash Tiles Moving on Save
videos.description: We finally got to the root of a frustrating bug that was moving visualizations on the dashboard after unrelated edits.
videos.author: Chris Merrick

videos.title: More Drafts Preview
videos.description: Luke gives us another demo of the soon-to-release drafts workflow.
videos.author: Luke Bowerman

videos.title: Parameterized Connections with User Attributes
videos.description: New tooling that allows database connections to be parameterized via user attributes. This offers some optionality around permissioning (secure connection vs open connection) or even allowing large Snowflake warehouses for specific users or use cases.
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Embed User Permissions Changes
videos.description: We've tuned the handling of embed user permissions. Rather than using connection defaults, now external embed users will require explicit permission setting in the URL construction. This makes app intent more clear and offers more nuance for internal/external shared deployments.
videos.author: Nate Agrin

Now descriptions can be used to tune the AI query in Omni. This allows a vehicle for passing example filter values or other metadata to improve hit rates.

A quick preview of history of drafted and archive dashboards. This now means not only workbook querying and visualization can be versioned, but also dashboard layouts. This will launch as part of the new publishing workflows.

A few fun themes we made to celebrate Halloween and dashboard CSS controls.

We improved the resolution on PDFs to improve the mobile dashboard experience in particular.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: The beta launch of locking the vis config. While evolving the vis config dynamically as you query can be helpful in normal circumstances, when configs have been highly adjusted, locking the configuration to prevent updates on query structure changes offers a new alternative.

More work on our intelligent autocomplete for both SQL and the IDE, allowing psuedo instant field compilation from even comments. Show a nice example from the SQL block of a comment that automatically generates a query on the fly.
Some significant improvements to search over massive database schemas.
Some mostly invisible tweaks to how SQL is compiled with templating, reducing rare errors and improving performance.
Some new improvements to column header renaming, avoiding accidental resorts and making the app more delightful.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A brand new set of controls to label filter values, and pass said labels through as dynamic text. Now filter text can be explicitly set and these values can pass through to fields for things like period-over-period or other filter-only field use case.

New deeper git support for customers with and Omni repo that is not main. More functionality to understand the current overall state in the content validator - how much is errored and filtering to only errored content.
New controls to set default timeframes from the default set in Omni (date, week, month, quarter, year). Now can be modeled explicitly.
More work on draft-publish workflows with rich history on all of the drafts associated with a workbook or dashboard, and function to restore these drafts as well.
Clearer distinction between static schemas and dbt schemas in the IDE for easier model management.

Some pre-launch work and some conversation on locking the vis config to never reset user-inputted changes. This would mean that even with significant query mutation, any user-facing input would remain in the visualization, reducing re-work over changes.
Richer UX for setting custom colors on a given visualization, mirroring the improved UX for global color palettes.
The last piece of work to put global color palettes into GA, allowing custom global palettes to pass to the renderer for downloads and scheduling.
A quick set of demo dashboards with stylized tables and charts for the NBA, using public data.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A new UI mode for writing dbt SQL (ie. Jinja + refs). Now for handwritten SQL folks can toggle into dbt SQL mode for confirming well composed SQL and results before pushing to dbt.
An early look at a new always-git mode for schema refresh. Soon development team will have the option to also force schema refreshes through a pull request workflow.
Continuing work on drafts in Omni, this also offers content-level and global toggles for dashboard permissions, like blocking download or scheduling.

Some experimental work + conversation about adding more visual types to the data model. Here we show some special handlers for hex colors that enable a more visual experience for end users. This also sets up the groundwork for more style controls in the UI like pills for categorical fields, modeled conditional formatting, checkboxes, etc.
The launch of global color palettes for everyone. A bit of final cleanup to make sure these palettes carry to the renderer, and we show off a nice example in production.
A quick demo of the live experience for period-over-period with time controls, so now even time dimensions can flexibly pull offsetting time periods with a couple clicks.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: The launch of embedded content management controls. Now users in the embed context can build and share content with teammates seamlessly.

Soon to launch map regions on zoomable, pannable maps. This will launch out of the box with the most common maps (countries, states, zips), but also offers BYO shape files for map charting on nearly anything in Omni.

Now period-over-period can be filtered measures series that can work as independent series as well as pivots. This opens up much simpler calcs (think % change, and absolute change with a couple clicks) and flexible arrangement. Plus a bunch of UX improvements to flattening pivots.

A quick demo of running the query application plane entirely inside Snowflake. This will allow Omni to deploy entirely outside our infrastructure for Snowflake native apps or other deployments inside customer infrastructure.
We've polished up the controls for axis ticks, especially for time groups. Now builders will have fine-grain ability to tune axis breakpoints.

We've opened up size controls in our advanced Vega Lite spec. This opens up the opportunity for trellising with some hand tuning of sizing. This is a precursor to trellis / grid visualization controls natively in vis.
The open launch of our global color palette controls, along with some more elegant change management for folks tuning global palettes over time.
Opening up a few more time configuration controls for vis.
Now folks can take advantage of the new drafts workflow optionally. Still a bit of cleanup to do for full launch, but now the full draft experience is testable by any user in the app.

Some improvements to warn when out-of-sync model changes may overwrite intermediate changes. Now instead of developers stomping on each other editing, simple warnings can avoid unintentional overwrites.
Our new script for maintaining live Omni content in Google Sheets without Zapier.

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets:
A huge step forward in the flexibility of working with pivoted data. Now pivots can be instantly turned into filtered measures. This opens up a variety of new functionality:

Flexible layout of calculations - work with pivots just like simpler data

Color controls over pivoted series

Rearranging pivot order ad hoc

Keeping the top N pivots and allocating other series to "other"
Flexible layout of calculations - work with pivots just like simpler data
Color controls over pivoted series
Rearranging pivot order ad hoc
Keeping the top N pivots and allocating other series to "other"

Lots of embedded progress

A preview of the embedded content system for saving and sharing ad hoc control inside a given tenants

Increasingly folks are building data products with full design input - we want to make it as simple as possible for design teams to be productive in their own tools. So we've released new tools for embedded builders to design using Omni components.

New controls for setting light / dark / dynamic for embedded URLs. This means embedded builders can control their experience a bit more for end users.
A preview of the embedded content system for saving and sharing ad hoc control inside a given tenants

New controls for tick count on the axis, allowing more sparse axis value labels - especially relevant for smaller numbers or non-decimals.

Soon to launch region maps in Omni. Here we demo states, but zip and countries will also be launching soon.

New config that opens up color controls on native lat, long maps

summary_bullets: A first look at global color palette controls - now manage palettes for the Omni environment including diverging and gradient palettes with a full admin UI

Why isn't calling data from another query as easy as Excel or Sheets? Just reference the field and put data next to each other. Now you can with simple cross-sheet cell references to bring queries next to each other without joins or models or lookups, just "="

The launch of sticky vis config over a huge number of user actions in the UI. Smarter, better visualization as you refine queries in the app - sticky colors, retaining changes between different vis types, smarter retention of facets on new fields.
New settings for git to create branches for pull requests created outside of Omni, for more robust change management in product for folks using git outside the app
New dynamic schema controls with dbt
Smarter branch creation - adding existing changes on save to the new branches
Controls to download hidden columns for curated data tables
A new API to manage embed users (list, delete), in order to manage privacy deletion in bulk
The ability to push down more TEXT() metrics to the model - for both numeric formats like percent or decimal, and datetime formats
New controls to re-assign ownership for content
Better validation for joins through the context of topics
Grouping measures inside pivots to cluster metrics instead of dimensions
Folding in the IDE to open up quicker, easier navigation in large topics or view files
A quick design pattern for aliased joins inside topics, including renaming metrics specific to the topic (instead of globally)

weeks_detail.title: Demos
summary_bullets: A first look at the new saving and editing workflow for workbooks. This is a full rebuild of the editing workflow that underpins content as code as well as simpler deployment of complex changes, including alongside model changes. Plenty of discussion as well on how to tune the experience as we approach launch.
The launch of scheduling to SFTP servers from Omni. Now recurring data delivery use cases for customers and partners can be served trivially from the UI.

An early look at bringing the entire folder and navigation system for dashboards to embedded users. All of the saving and curation of dashboards in the core app will soon be accessible to any embedded deployment as well.

New functionality to ignore query-specific filters in favor of a filtered measure's specific filters. This allows for escaping filters comparing to population totals over specific filters, and also underpins some new work for removing pivots from period-over-period for way easier calculations and layouts.
Improved handling of large models in the IDE. Instead of loading everything too frequently, we manage the payload to reduce network traffic and speed up page loads for modelers.
Quick new feature to allow tuning the topic for a dashboard filter without rebuilding or remapping.

summary_bullets: New functionality to create links between embedded dashboards *inside* the iframe. No more tearing down and rebuilding iframes, just super fast linking to make navigation feel 100% native.
A pair of Zapier hooks to directly drop data into Google Sheets from Omni - functionality for both creating a new tab with data or overwriting the existing scheduled object.

More work on calculations and sorting of SQL results - all the Excel goodness on top of raw SQL queries. Also some nice improvements to space management for SQL including drag sizing on the SQL block.
The near-launch of abstract model objects - allowing complex model and field layering, and setting up the groundwork for remote dependencies in the data model

Suggest from topic - for when you want to curate filter suggests based on a specific topic rather than the default behavior

The launch of dynamic connections in branches

New mode to write dbt SQL from the UI, including {{ }} references

Lots of improvements to filters - cleaner, searchable dropdowns, better load experience for single select
Layered templated filters for complex model parameterization
A quick demo of an advanced vis with sparse data labels as we build out native coverage

videos.title: Dashboard Filter Improvements
videos.description: A bit more work to improve performance when filters are left empty.

videos.title: Table Header Styling
videos.description: New controls to truncate columns headers to two lines. Always trying to make sure styling is in full control, and defaults look great.

videos.title: Dashboard Themes / Styling Manager
videos.description: Now dashboard styling (CSS, fonts, colors, backgrounds) can be stored into themes that can be used on any dashboard. This new UX allows styling directly in the app, and easy management for consistent, custom styles with minimum effort.

videos.title: Dashboard Vanity URLs
videos.description: New settings for vanity dashboard URLs, making navigation simple and contextual - now it's as easy as dashboard/CorporateDash instead of dashboard/1 or dashboard/lkjdfs (unless you want that!). This also means that you can more easily make updates to an embedded dashboard without requiring an engineer to point from one identifier to another, by instead pointing to a fixed, immutable URL.

videos.title: XLOOKUP and Filter-by-Query Portability
videos.description: Moving queries across workbooks is usually simple, but not when your queries reference other queries - until now. Now you can move queries with XLOOKUPs or queries with filters from other queries to any workbook, and the dependencies come with - no more thinking, all just works.

videos.title: SQL with Sorts, Column Labels, and Calcs
videos.description: A first look at our effort to bring all of the Omni goodness to SQL queries as well. Instead of forcing users to wedge calculations or column relabels or sorts into the SQL block, now it's just simple actions on top of the result table. Little bit more work to do here, but coming soon.

videos.title: in_query Model Parameters
videos.description: More flexibility for your data models - in_query allows for dynamic SQL generation based upon the structure of your query. This opens up all sorts of new use cases for flexible SQL based upon the filters or columns selected.

videos.title: Period-Over-Period with Time Columns
videos.description: The finishing touches on our period-over-period implementation now offer dynamic time offsets even with other time fields selected. An easy way to pull up time offsets without impacting the structure of your baseline query.

videos.title: Dynamic Database Connections
videos.description: New functionality that allows for dynamically swapping the database connection from a branch. Easily switch between prod or staging schemas (not just dbt) in the UI - great for testing data models across mirrored databases during migration or other more complex deployment use cases.

videos.title: Snowflake Key-Pair Authentication
videos.description: Some fresh code for using key-pair authentication with Snowflake - providing an extra layer of security to basic authentication (ie. username and password) when accessing your Snowflake. Wrapping up code review and tests on it, we expect it to be live next week.

videos.title: Views in Topics
videos.description: Sometimes you need to customize a view for the purpose of a single topic - new labels, new fields, maybe even different field definitions. Now you can. This work opens up a views: argument inside topics, that allow for ad hoc view declaration, extension, or overrides, without impacting the core view files. Enormous flexibility with this feature to customize topics to any use case - now everything is fair game inside the topic specifically.

videos.title: IDE Redesigns
videos.description: A whole bunch of design prototypes for upcoming work on the IDE. Easier joins and topics, better navigation, lots of metadata and in-line documentation.

videos.title: Field Picker In-Use Toggle
videos.description: A new filter control to quickly view only the fields in use for a given query (dimensions, measures, pivots, or filters)

videos.title: Editing Visualization From the Dashboard
videos.description: Some very early prototypes for editing visualizations directly on the dashboard. The goal is to avoid bouncing back and forth to the workbook when tuning visualizations. Lots of work to do here to launch, but hopefully paints the picture of a much better editing experience.

videos.title: Single Pick Filters
videos.description: A first look at new single-select filters on dashboards, removing the complexity of picking a filter type, and simply requiring a single filter input for a dashboard (think Customer Lookup, Region Picker, etc).

videos.title: Filter Suggestion Cache Busting
videos.description: New controls that allow for refreshing the filter suggestion cache. Making sure all the entries from the database are available for suggestions.

videos.title: Dashboard Filter Faceting Controls
videos.description: New explicitly controls for whether one filter filter's the suggestions of another filter. Can be turned on or off as needed for the desired experience.

videos.title: Period-Over-Period Dashboard Controls
videos.description: Now all the goodness of period-over-period controls is available from the dashboard as well.

videos.title: Single Tile Schedules - Bigger Vis
videos.description: Now when single tile visualizations are scheduled, the visualizations are sized up for easier consumption.

videos.title: Period-Over-Period Compare to Last Period
videos.description: A new option for a period-over-period offset to the previous same-length period. Want to look at 20-day performance vs previous 20-days, or 37-month vs 37-month - all out of the box now.

videos.title: Calling Filters in Markdown
videos.description: Now it's much easier to use a given query's filter configuration in markdown, allowing for easier drill down to dashboards or other queries in Omni.

videos.title: Model Automatic Error Fixing!
videos.description: The most difficult part about maintaining a data environment is the constant cleanup required as business logic evolves and transforms. Inevitably, the outcome is errors in the data model. Instead of fixing them one-by-one, what if they just resolved themselves? Our new IDE errors now have a button to do just that! Model cleanup is now as easy as accepting cleanup suggestions. Incredibly excited for this one for our own environment as well :)

videos.description: Massive improvements to data compression for large payloads, sometimes reducing data sizes by upwards of 50% for large data sets

videos.title: Dashboard Filters in Content Validator
videos.description: A bit more tuning to handle filters in the content validator - making sure dashboards are immune to schema changes.

videos.description: Default row-level access controls. Now rather than encoding access-filters on individual topics, they can be default-set globally. A new best practice for embedded deployments to lock up data by default, even through topics.
videos.author: Conrad Slimmer

videos.title: Snowflake Native App
videos.description: A first look at work on our Snowflake native app, with the full app deployed in Snowflake alongside the database

videos.description: New functionality to move legends around. Starting with left/right, the next focus of work will be on bottom/top legends. Some better erroring as well.

videos.title: Access boost Through Access Grants Controls
videos.description: A new control to allow access boost through grants. In rare cases with topic or column security, the raw data can remain locked, but optionally poked through on a specific piece of content. Will not allow for access filter (row-level) passthrough.
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Front-End Drill Path Controls
videos.description: Everyone wants to sidestep modeling in the model, now drill paths can be controlled from the workbook - easier ad hoc drilling, and, like everything else, promotable to the shared data model

videos.title: Scheduling Single Tiles on Dashboards
videos.description: The launch of single-tile scheduling. Now folks can send just one tile from a workbook or dashboard. Next up is alerts.
videos.author: Luke Bowerman

videos.title: Filter by Query
videos.description: The results of one tab can now be used as a filter for another query. This enables filtering for user lists or other ID sets (or even multiple user groups!) and then passing the results to another query. This opens up fast cohorting or on-the-fly analyses to end users without SQL.
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Field Swappers on the Dashboard
videos.description: The addition of field swappers to dashboards (still a work in progress). Soon swapping between dimensions, swapping between measures, or swapping between timeframes can be done through the filter UX on dashboards. More interactivity for end users.
videos.author: Jamie Davidson

videos.title: New permissions reporting
videos.description: No demo for this one, but here's a screenshot (names and emails hashed, but viewable and drillable in-app)!

videos.title: XLOOKUP
videos.description: The launch of xlookup, bringing cross-tab analysis to any user. Now time series joins across tabs, fact lookups, etc are trivial in the workbook - continuing the strategy of bringing the best of spreadsheets into Omni.
videos.author: Cathy Lennon

videos.title: Embedded Workbooks
videos.description: A first look at the embedded workbook experience; now customers can share full analytical experiences with their customers alongside curated dashboards in embedded use cases
videos.author: Gustav Staprans

videos.title: Dynamic Fields / Select Fields From Filters
videos.description: The launch of dynamic fields in Omni, allowing tables columns to be controlled by filters entirely in the front-end - timegrain swappers, dimension swappers, and measure swappers are now available for flexible analysis workflows (dashboard support coming soon)
videos.author: Jamie Davidson

videos.title: Parameters / Filter Passing into Fields
videos.description: Filters can now be injected into fields for parameterized reporting - opening up use cases like dynamic formatting, forecasting, or simply filters that can pass to calcs in the UI
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Filter Passing Between Dashboards
videos.description: Now model urls arguments can accept dashboard filters for complete context on cross-drilling experiences (passing the full filter context from one dashboard to another)
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: dbt Dynamic Schema Migration
videos.description: New tooling to migrate a data model to dynamic schemas. This opens up the ability to test dbt changes on test schemas across the full app.

videos.title: More Tables - Descriptions, Conditional Formatting Bars
videos.description: Lots of work on tables: optional field descriptions in the table; touch-up to allow conditional formatting on table bar charts, and a bunch of polish across the table experience
videos.author: Richard Czechowski

videos.title: Period-Over-Period Clean-Up
videos.description: Some touch-ups to the period-over-period experience to clearly explain the time slices
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Bring Your Own Aggregates / In-Database Aggregate Awareness
videos.description: Bring your own aggregates - aggregate awareness can now be configured in the data model for objects like dbt roll-ups. These can then be dynamic queries to reduce spend and improve performance. This will complement the browser-based DuckDB aggregate awareness.
videos.author: Steven Talbot

videos.title: Embed Post Requests / Embed Messaging System

videos.description: New functionality for banding and capping with conditional formatting.

videos.description: The end of third party cookies for embedding. Now Omni dashboards can use vanity URLs to match the parent domain and avoid third-party cookies and more restrictive browser issues.

videos.description: More work to allow auto-scaling for Omni's infrastructure. This ensures maximum performance for even the heaviest workloads.

videos.description: Bringing all the goodness of formatting in the formula to Omni, now the TEXT() function is available. Often useful when concatenating formatted data and text in a cell.

videos.description: Lots of work on keeping query pipelines sustainable. Here we demo some work to open up controls for user and organizational level query throttling to ensure the database isn't over-exercised

videos.description: More work on organizing dashboards and workbooks, here bringing the tag system to folders.
